page.title: 19FARMING (CONTINUED)
page.content:
2) The upland farms, on poorer ground and with a less equable climate, are mainly family run. They have more traditional herds of cattle and sheep flocks. Most of the land is managed to provide stock feed - grazing grass, hay, silage, and turnips. Cash crops of barley and potatoes are also grown. The living on these farms is more precarious - recent fine summers have given good crops, but this year has seen the wettest and least sunny summer for thirty years, leading to serious losses of the cereal crop.
The winter climate is such that indoor wintering of cattle is the norm, and winter feed is provided for the sheep. Lambing ranges from the New Year (indoors) to April.
